title: The Taliban's Aug. 31 'Red Line'
summary: Now we know why Biden wants all U.S. troops out of Kabul in a week.. One of the mysteries of the last 10 days is President Biden's reluctance to say a discouraging word about the Taliban. He's been far tougher on our Afghanistan allies than on the jihadists who have taken over the country and humiliated the U.S. The reason is almost certainly that Mr. Biden feels he needs the Taliban's cooperation to get Americans out of harm's way in Kabul.

title: The Agony of the 'Centrist' Democrats
summary: Pelosi views them as cannon fodder, and they'll probably cave.. With the House back in town, the debate for Democrats is which colossal plan they should pass first: President Biden's $1 trillion infrastructure package? Or Bernie Sanders's $3.5 trillion budget outline? The media is covering it as a real showdown but, if history holds, this will turn out to be Kabuki theater.

title: Kathy Hochul's Charter Opportunity
summary: New York's next Governor can stand for children over unions.. Lt. Gov. Kathy Hochul takes over as New York Governor on Tuesday, replacing a scandal-ridden Andrew Cuomo. New Yorkers are looking for her to change business-as-usual in Albany, and she can send a powerful signal of change by pushing state legislators to lift the cap on charter schools.

title: The FDA's Vaccine Sprint
summary: Full approval for Pfizer's mRNA shot should boost public confidence.. Hear, hear to the Food and Drug Administration, which moved mountains of paperwork to grant Pfizer 's mRNA vaccine full approval on Monday-in record time amid complaints that the delay was contributing to public vaccine hesitancy.

title: Police Vindicate the 'Thin Blue Line' Patch Every Day
summary: A symbol is banned for making people feel unsafe. But police aren't the real danger to urban dwellers.. The village of Mount Prospect, Ill., prohibited its police officers earlier this month from wearing a "thin blue line" patch on their uniforms. The patch consists of a black-and-white U.S. flag with one blue stripe. It honors fallen cops and recognizes the role police play in protecting society from anarchy. Detractors insist the symbol makes people of color feel unsafe. Police chiefs and elected officials in San Francisco, Middletown and Manchester, Conn., and elsewhere have banned it.

title: A Simple Rule Could End Debt-Ceiling Shenanigans
summary: Federal debt may face a downgrade if Democrats and Republicans don't agree to increase the limit.. It's time to bring back the Gephardt Rule.

title: Notable & Quotable: War
summary: 'Those who have never fought for the colors they fly should be careful about criticizing those who have.'. Tom Tugendhat, a Conservative member and veteran of Afghanistan, speaking in Britain's House of Commons Aug. 18:

title: The Deeper Crisis Behind the Afghan Rout
summary: Observers abroad see the culmination of decades of American incompetence.. The good news for the Biden administration is that the latest NBC News poll reports 25% approval of President Biden's handling of the situation in Afghanistan. Foreign support is even harder to find. North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies are horrified, and Greece completed a border wall to keep out the expected flood of refugees. Arab countries are worried, India and Israel depressed. China and Russia are scornful.

title: A Taliban 9/11
summary: Joe Biden rushed the Afghanistan pullout for a political speech he wanted to give.. What on earth will Joe Biden say this Sept. 11?

title: 'Smarter Tomorrow' Review: Better Brains
summary: To improve the way our minds function, a science educator recommends we spend a little time each day 'neurohacking.'. Working at home has led to widescale experimentation in productivity. Many workers, no longer tied to central offices, are trying new schedules, locations, routines and work-life arrangements. But this has been a haphazard process, nothing like a controlled scientific study. Those interested in adding rigor to their self-improvement journeys have no better place to turn than "Smarter Tomorrow: How 15 Minutes of Neurohacking a Day Can Help You Work Better, Think Faster, and Get More Done," by the science educator and advocate Elizabeth Ricker. (Neurohacking, to put it simply, is finding shortcuts to a better-functioning brain).

title: Henri Deluges Northeast With Rain
summary: Thousands remain without power in Rhode Island after storm. Crews worked to restore power across Rhode Island, and forecasters warned of heavy rain and flash floods Monday as Henri weakened while moving east.

title: Intel Wins Defense Department Award for Domestic Chip Making
summary: Department of Defense aims to help develop U.S. ecosystem to fabricate products required for critical systems. Intel Corp. said it would provide commercial foundry services in the first phase of a broader Defense Department program that aims to build up domestic design and production of cutting-edge chips.

title: Too Few Goods, Too Few Workers
summary: Shortages generally lead to higher prices.. Last week your humble correspondent found several empty shelves at each of two Indiana department stores. This week the proprietor of a Massachusetts diner reports that he can't find needed kitchen staff. The restaurateur adds that he has personally enjoyed 1.5 days off work since the spring of 2020. Anecdotes aside, many businesses continue to run short of supplies and labor, suggesting prices for both will continue to rise.

title: Former Salvadoran Soccer Official Pleads Guilty in FIFA Case
summary: Reynaldo Vasquez, a former president of El Salvador's national soccer federation, pleads guilty to one count of racketeering. A former Salvadoran soccer official pleaded guilty to charges stemming from a years-old corruption case involving the world soccer-governing body FIFA.

title: Covid-19 Vaccines, Delta Variant and Kids: What to Know
summary: More children are getting infected with Covid-19 as the Delta variant spreads, though the risks of hospitalization and death remain low. The highly contagious Delta variant of Covid-19 is tearing through the U.S., driving up infections, just days before the start of the school year. More children are getting infected with the virus since the strain began circulating this summer. Here's what you need to know:

summary: Exhibitions at the Petersen celebrate the automaker's technical excellence and racing accolades.. Los Angeles

summary: Investors seem to have closed the book on Proposition 22, but there are more adventures to be had. For gig economy investors, Proposition 22 might have been too good to be true.

summary: Nasdaq Composite advances 1.5% as investors await more guidance from the Fed. U.S. stocks edged up Monday, boosted by technology stocks and full approval for Pfizer Inc.'s Covid-19 vaccine.

title: Haiti's Security Woes Disrupt Earthquake Relief
summary: Aid trucks have been looted, doctors kidnapped and foreign rescue teams evacuated. Crime, gangs and mob violence are disrupting efforts to deliver food and medical aid to tens of thousands of Haitians more than a week after a deadly earthquake.

summary: Pentagon, NYC schools will now require vaccinations as Biden calls on more employers to follow suit. title: U.S. Capitol Police Clear Officer Who Shot Ashli Babbitt During Jan. 6 Riot
summary: Internal probe concludes officer acted lawfully, adhered to department policy in fatal shooting. WASHINGTON-The police officer who shot and killed Ashli Babbitt during the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol won't face discipline after a monthslong internal investigation cleared him of any wrongdoing.

title: Firefight Erupts at Kabul Airport, While Taliban Affirm Deadline
summary: Gunbattle highlights security challenge as foreign forces struggle to evacuate thousands from Afghanistan by Aug. 31. A gunbattle broke out at Kabul's international airport on Monday amid a deteriorating security situation, as the Taliban said they wouldn't allow any extension of the U.S.-led operation to evacuate foreigners and allies from Afghanistan.

title: 'We Love NYC: The Homecoming Concert' Review: Short-Circuited Celebration
summary: The Central Park concert was supposed to mark New York's grand reopening following Covid-19, but lightning from Hurricane Henri meant that performers like Bruce Springsteen, Paul Simon, Patti Smith and the Killers never saw the stage..

summary: The contemporary home set on 25 acres features a 3,800-square-foot atrium and five pointed copper roofs. A house in Nevada built in the 1960s by the late Charles Steen, who is known for discovering rich uranium deposits in Utah, is listing for $30 million.

summary: Designed by architect Clarence Mayhew, the home comes with a massive atrium and, in the dining room, an island that appears to float on water.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

summary: Is school safe? Soccer? Birthday parties? Doctors suggest some principles to guide decision-making for parents with unvaccinated children. With the Delta variant of Covid-19 infecting more children, many parents are worried about how to keep their unvaccinated young kids safe as schools reopen and extracurricular activities resume.

title: Mayim Bialik to Temporarily Host 'Jeopardy!' After Mike Richards Stepped Down
summary: Actress is scheduled to tape 15 episodes when production resumes; additional guest hosts will be announced. Actress Mayim Bialik will temporarily host "Jeopardy!," taking over Mike Richards's spot after the game show's executive producer stepped down shortly after getting the coveted role.

title: Afghanistan's Disintegrating Economy Puts Pressure on the Taliban to Negotiate
summary: Banks remain closed amid shortage of cash as dollar shipments, foreign aid halted. No longer facing serious military opposition, Afghanistan's new Taliban rulers are grappling with a new threat: an economic collapse that could fuel renewed challenges to their rule and has already put pressure on them to share power.

title: U.S. Expansion Slowed in August, Survey Shows
summary: Factories and service providers report sharply slower growth due to the Delta variant and troubles in hiring, shipping. U.S. factories and service providers reported sharply slower growth in August, the forecasting firm IHS Markit said Monday in its surveys of purchasing managers.

title: New York City Mandates Covid-19 Vaccines for All Teachers, Staff
summary: Nation's largest school district says staff can't opt out or teach remotely. All staff in New York City schools will be required to get at least one Covid-19 vaccine dose before Sept. 27, following the Food and Drug Administration's full approval of the Pfizer Inc. vaccine, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Monday.

title: How Does the 14-Step Visa Program for Foreign Interpreters Work?
summary: Congress is pressing the White House to ramp up evacuations to help Afghan allies who risked their lives to help the U.S. military. Since the U.S. invasion of Afghanistan in 2001, tens of thousands of Afghans have worked alongside the U.S. military as interpreters, linguists and fixers. With the Taliban's takeover of the country, that affiliation with the U.S. has placed a target on their backs-and they are desperate to flee the country.

title: Chevron Requires Some Employees to Receive Vaccine
summary: The company requires some employees to get vaccinations and is considering broader requirements as the virus infects workers in Gulf of Mexico, Permian Basin. Chevron Corp. has begun requiring some employees to receive Covid-19 vaccinations and is evaluating mandates throughout its entire workforce as the oil-and-gas industry contends with rising infections, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: U.S. Home Sales Rise Amid Higher Inventory
summary: Median price was $359,900, easing from a record level in prior month. The U.S. housing market remained strong in July, with sales of previously owned homes rising at a faster pace than the prior month as high prices prompted owners to put more properties on the market.

title: Al Capone's Last Haul: The Gangster's Family Auctions His Mementos
summary: Capone's granddaughters are selling a trove of keepsakes; ethicists debate the value of objects of historical significance but moral murkiness. Call it Al Capone's final haul. A trove of family mementos, jewelry and weapons that were once owned by the notorious gangster will be auctioned off by his three surviving granddaughters, who lived in relative obscurity until they emerged in 2019.

title: The Afghan Who Won't Surrender to the Taliban
summary: Ahmad Massoud leads the resistance in the province of Panjshir. Can he and his fighters hold out?. Ahmad Massoud is in a remote base in Afghanistan's Panjshir province. He is the son and successor to the legendary commander Ahmad Shah Massoud, a resistance leader against both the Soviets and the Taliban until the latter assassinated him on Sept. 9, 2001.

title: She-lection Gives New Meaning to Suffer-age
summary: I wish Justin Trudeau would go take a giant leap for 'people-kind.'. Toronto

title: What's Henri's Path: What to Know About the Storm Hitting the East Coast
summary: Tracking Henri as it is downgraded to a tropical depression. Henri was downgraded to a tropical depression Sunday evening from a Category 1 hurricane in the morning. Long Island and New England braced for possible storm surges, heavy rain and strong winds.

title: Vox Media Agrees to Acquire Punch, Weighs Going Public
summary: Digital media company is buying a cocktail website founded by Bertelsmann's Penguin Random House. Vox Media LLC said Monday it is buying Punch, a cocktail website founded by Bertelsmann SE's Penguin Random House, part of a bid to deepen its coverage of food and drinks.

title: Fed Chairman Powell Navigates the Inflation Debate
summary: The Federal Reserve confers this week, and Mr. Powell is expected to clarify the central bank's position. He battles internal dissension over how to proceed, and a haywire economic recovery hampered by the Delta variant.. After a decade of low growth and inflation, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell unveiled a new strategy a year ago in which the central bank would keep interest rates lower for longer.

title: College Football Gets Honest With Itself
summary: A sport that used to wrap itself in nostalgia and school pride now fully embraces its capitalist future. The college football season is nearly here, and you've likely read about seismic stuff afoot-Texas and Oklahoma slinking off from the Big 12 to the Southeastern Conference, an expanded playoff, the Big Ten/Pac-12/ACC alliance, the potential for more conference reshuffling, and, most excitingly, offensive linemen being paid in barbecue gift cards.

title: Former Anchorage Restructuring Head Joins Investment Bank PJT
summary: Charles Tauber played a major role in the New York hedge fund's investments in distressed companies. Investment bank PJT Partners Inc. has hired the former U.S. head of restructuring at hedge fund Anchorage Capital Group as a partner, said people familiar with the matter.

title: China's Antigraft Watchdog Probes Party Officials in Alibaba, Ant's Backyard
summary: Investigation raises questions about close ties between local top-level Communist Party members and the private sector. HONG KONG-China's anticorruption watchdog is investigating top government officials in the eastern Chinese city of Hangzhou, where Alibaba Group Holding Ltd and Ant Group Co. are based, raising questions about close ties between local top-level Communist Party officials and the private sector.

title: Stakeholder Capitalism Is Slowly Advancing
summary: Count on mounting public and institutional pressure.. Lucian Bebchuk and Roberto Tallarita's op-ed "'Stakeholder' Talk Proves Empty Again" (Aug. 19) is probably correct, as far as it goes. On its face, the Business Roundtable's statement is far from having been meaningfully implemented. Market pressures from investors to sustain profits are substantial.

title: Bitcoin Prices Pass $50,000 for First Time Since May
summary: The cryptocurrency has steadily made up ground since slumping earlier in year. Bitcoin prices topped $50,000 for the first time in three months Monday.

title: Irresponsible Gender-Transition Treatments on Children
summary: There is little supporting scientific evidence on long-term harms and benefits.. The endorsement by the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) of hormonal and other treatments for gender transitions in children and adolescents is astonishing ("A Pediatric Association Stifles Debate on Gender Dysphoria" by Abigail Shrier, op-ed, Aug. 10). There is probably no medical treatment that is so widely used in this group of patients that has so little supporting scientific evidence on long-term harms and benefits.

title: Target to Add More Disney Shops to Stores
summary: Retailer will also offer selection of Target-only toys and games ahead of the holiday season. Target Corp. said it plans to triple the number of Disney shops it operates within its stores to more than 160 in the U.S. by the end of the year as the retailer has seen a pickup in toy sales.

title: High-Schoolers Get a Pass and Oregon Fails
summary: Apparently, standards of proficiency are racist.. Oregon's desire to have minority students achieve academic parity by eliminating proficiency requirements ("Dumbing Oregon Down," Review & Outlook, Aug. 13) reminds me of a story from one of my economic professors: "An economist entered a room and remarked how cold the room was. He went to a wall thermometer and confirmed that the room was 45 degrees and, yes, quite cool. He then struck a match and placed the flame under the thermometer until it read 75 degrees. "Aaaah, that's much better," he said. Some things never change.

title: Where Was Sen. Grassley on the State Tax Deduction?
summary: The Biden administration would recklessly tax people until the productive value system is destroyed.. I have rarely seen a piece of special pleading as blatant as Sen. Chuck Grassley's objection to a change in the estate tax ("A 'Death Knell' Tax Threatens Family Farms and Businesses," op-ed, Aug. 12). He complains that taxing an estate on unrealized capital gains, by eliminating the step-up in basis, would "dismantle a century-old tax law that has stitched the economic and social fabric." Mr. Grassley showed no similar solicitude for Americans in high tax states when he supported the 2017 tax reform, which deprived citizens of those states of the right to deduct state tax payments from their income in calculating federal tax liability. That right had existed for more than a century.

title: Boeing Plans Investment in Virgin Orbit's $3.2 Billion SPAC Listing
summary: Plane maker's investment comes as its own space program faces hurdles. Richard Branson's Virgin Orbit said Boeing Co. will invest in the satellite-launching startup's planned $3.2 billion SPAC listing later this year, an investment that comes as the plane maker's own space program faces hurdles.

title: Afghanistan Withdrawal Mess Risks Second Wave of Problems
summary: Chaos undermines core Biden messages about competent government and the superiority of democracies as well as relations with U.S. allies. In foreign policy, as in other areas of human endeavor, the law of unintended consequences is cruel but always in effect.

title: Cryptocurrency's Surge Leaves Global Watchdogs Trying to Catch Up
summary: Binance and BitMEX exchanges have come under regulatory pressure, but coordinated crypto oversight seems limited in the U.S., Europe and Asia. The cryptocurrency industry is getting so big and enabling so much risk-taking that governments around the globe are taking notice.

title: 40 Previously Unseen Slim Aarons Photos, to Conjure the Vacation You Wish You Were On
summary: Go poolside in these archival images from the photographer-king of warm-weather leisure.. The photographer Slim Aarons summed up his subject matter best: "Attractive people doing attractive things in attractive places." His images were for decades a mainstay of Life, Holiday and other magazines and more recently have filled coffee-table books. Slim Aarons: Style (Abrams, $85) is the latest of these; out this month, it contains 40 previously unpublished images.

title: Kristen Bell Is Not a Morning Person
summary: The actress loves sleep, enjoys the mental health benefits of exercise and sees herself in the characters she plays.. Strong-willed, feisty, funny, brave, hopeful, clumsy and awkward are all words that might describe Anna, the lovably idiosyncratic character in Disney 's 2013 hit Frozen. They're also apt descriptors for Kristen Bell, the actress who voices her. "She wasn't originally written like that," says Bell, 41. "It was a deliberate choice because I, as an 11-year-old girl watching Disney movies, had never seen anyone like me who had bad posture and tripped a lot and didn't say the perfect thing. I wanted to make something for all the quirky little girls."

title: Shariah Law, Women's Rights in Afghanistan and the Taliban: What to Know
summary: Taliban takeover has stirred concerns that the group will impose its draconian interpretation of Sunni Islam on women and girls. In the wake of the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan, fears are growing that Afghan women will suffer the sort of harsh treatment they encountered during the 1990s, when the Taliban imposed their hard-line interpretation of Sunni Islam on them, a form of oppression that helped make Afghanistan a pariah state at the time.

summary: Aspiring hosts for 2036 and beyond include Indonesia, India, Germany and Qatar, the International Olympic Committee's Thomas Bach says. summary: Resume Subscription. When U.S. schools reopened for in-person learning last year, many districts had clear metrics for thresholds that would trigger school closures due to Covid-19. This year, more are taking a wait-and-see approach.

summary: Thursday may be the new Monday when it comes to strategizing what days in the office will get you the most face time with senior leaders; 'Your boss's schedule is your schedule'. title: Joy to the Word (Monday Crossword, August 23)
Oklahoma Woman to the Kabul Rescue
summary: Allyson Reneau took it upon herself to rescue 10 Afghan girls.. The vast bureaucracies of the White House, Pentagon and State Department may have been taken by surprise by what's unfolded in Afghanistan. But not Allyson Reneau. Thanks to this 60-year-old Oklahoma mother, 10 members of the Afghan Girls Robotics team have escaped from Afghanistan.

title: Rachel Maddow Strikes Multiyear Deal With MSNBC
summary: Deal keeps the network's highly rated cable host at NBCUniversal. Rachel Maddow, MSNBC's highly rated host, has signed a new deal that will keep her at the network for the next several years, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Pentagon Enlists Airlines to Help Afghan Evacuees
summary: Commercial planes won't fly to Kabul under program; Biden administration discusses extension of deadline for withdrawing U.S. troops. President Biden said Sunday that his administration may extend an Aug. 31 deadline for withdrawing troops from Afghanistan, as the Pentagon enlisted the help of U.S. airlines to evacuate Americans and Afghan partners from the country.
